div.p: I think, you know, when I was at school I felt I wasn’t capable of doing anything I mean I think I was told that. When I first left school
I got my first job working for a big national company in Gloucester and I had a lot of difficulties there because I really hid the fact that
I couldn’t read or hardly write, I had a friend of mine fill in the application form. And it became apparent very, very quickly that I had to do things
where you had to write things down and do those sort of things and it came out very, very quickly that I couldn’t manage those sort of things.
Even at that early stage at work people labelled you, I don’t know, “thick” or whatever but they did sort of label you that way or they would
treat you differently or talk to you differently because they thought you “weren’t quite right” you know there’s a label attached to you
in other words and that was difficult.
